overview: 2 Thessalonians addresses confusion about Christ's return. Some thought it had already happened; others quit working to wait for it. Paul clarifies events preceding the end and calls for faithful work.

verses.text: For even when we were with you, we would give you this command: If anyone is not willing to work, let him not eat.
So then, brothers, stand firm and hold to the traditions that you were taught by us, either by our spoken word or by our letter.
But the Lord is faithful. He will establish you and guard you against the evil one.

passages.title: The Day of the Lord
passages.summary: Paul clarifies that the day of the Lord hasn't come—certain events including the 'man of lawlessness' must happen first.

facts.text: Some Thessalonians had stopped working because they thought Christ's return was imminent. Paul corrects this.
The 'man of lawlessness' has been variously interpreted throughout church history—a future antichrist figure.
Paul's command about work ('if anyone is not willing to work, let him not eat') has influenced Christian work ethic for centuries.

figures.name: Paul
figures.description: The apostle correcting misunderstandings about Christ's return while modeling faithful work as an example.

videos.title: 2 Thessalonians Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores Paul's correction about the day of the Lord.
